metadata.case_name: Appellant (Public Limited Company) v. State of Assam & Ors.

facts.text: Appellant had exclusive privilege under contract with Government of Assam for supplying country spirit to two warehouses in District of Lakhimpur from July 1, 1967 to March 3, 1970.

Commissioner of Excise, Assam invited sealed tenders for privilege of supplying country spirit to retail vendors in Upper Assam area (Districts of Lakhimpur and Sibsagar including Mikir Sub-Division) for three years from April 1, 1970. Notification stated preference to manufacturers.
Appellant tendered at 74 P. per London proof litre; Respondent No. 5 at 95 P. per London proof litre; Rampur Distillery offered 60 P. but tender defective and rejected.
Government not satisfied with tenders; by letter dated February 28, 1970, asked tenderers to indicate willingness to reduce rates by March 10, 1970.
Only Respondent No. 5 responded; Managing Director by letter dated March 4, 1970 agreed to reduce rate and accept any rate fixed by Government as reasonable.
Government reduced Respondent No. 5's rate to 74 P. per London proof litre and accepted its tender.

Assam Government order dated June 16, 1970 granted contract to Respondent No. 5 for wholesale supply of country spirit to Tinsukia and North Lakhimpur warehouses for three years from July 1, 1970 to June 30, 1973.
Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 in Assam and Nagaland High Court (Civil Rule No. 431 of 1970) to quash Government order; rejected by judgment dated December 16, 1971.
No allegation of mala fides against Government.

legal_issues.text: Whether the impugned order of Assam Government dated June 16, 1970 granting contract to Respondent No. 5 violates Rule 93 of the Rules framed under the Eastern Bengal and Assam Excise Act, 1910.

petitioner_arguments.text: Impugned order cannot be sustained because Government nowhere stated that tenders were not acceptable on ground that none appeared satisfactory.
Under Rule 93, Government could not enter into negotiations with any tenderers.
Before concluding contract with Respondent No. 5, Government should have given opportunity to other tenderers to reduce rates.

court_reasoning.text: Government considered tenders unsatisfactory as evidenced by letter asking to reduce prices; clear from facts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: From facts, Government considered tenders unsatisfactory and hence unacceptable.

court_reasoning.text: Notification mentioned preference to manufacturers; prima facie nothing wrong; Government as purchaser can prefer one seller to another for good reasons like guarantee of supply; classification rational.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Preference to manufacturers justified; no rule prohibits it; falls under s.19 powers.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 93 does not prohibit negotiations with tenderers; authorizes negotiations with non-tenderers; no rational basis to prohibit with tenderers; Government can negotiate under s.19 to get cheapest rates and regular supplies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule 93 does not prohibit negotiations with tenderers.

court_reasoning.text: No fundamental right to Government contract; appellant given opportunity to tender, offer considered, not rejected irrationally; no question of hearing as no rights deprived; only fair play required.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No one has fundamental right to get Government contract; principles of natural justice not violated.

holdings.text: Impugned order does not violate Rule 93 or any statutory provision; s.19 confers wide powers on Government absent restrictive rules.

statutes_cited.name: Eastern Bengal and Assam Excise Act, 1910
statutes_cited.relevance: s.19 empowers Provincial Government to grant exclusive privilege of supplying country liquor; Rules 91-93 govern tender process but do not prohibit negotiations with tenderers or preference to manufacturers.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court petition to quash Government order.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; High Court order upheld; no order as to costs.

key_quotes.text: No one has a fundamental right to get a Government contract.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The Provincial Government may grant to any person... the exclusive privilege of manufacturing or of supplying... any country liquor... within any specified local area.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.19 highlighting wide Government powers.

key_quotes.text: In the very notification calling for tenders, it had been mentioned that preference will be given to the manufacturers.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies preference given to Respondent No. 5.
